Award.AwardTitle: Efficient Algorithms for Continuous Time Service Network Design Models that Accurately Estimate Consolidation Opportunities in Time

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the research supported by this award is the development of planning methods for in service systems that will enable high-velocity services in a cost-effective manner. The main motivation is in planning of transportation services by consolidation carriers. Consolidation carriers play a prominent role in order fulfillment and the supply chains that support product manufacturing. With the continued trend towards just-in-time practices, fast shipping requests in the retail sector are echoed in the supply chains providing the products ordered. As a result, many consolidation carriers are facing increased pressure to deliver goods in less time and at low cost. Transportation planning decisions for a consolidation carrier have both a geographic and temporal component. A common technique for handling time in planning models is discretization, which means that a model will include the decision that the dispatch occurs in a certain time window. The planning model will represent time at each facility with a series of windows, with the choice of windows determined a priori. Customer demands for rapid delivery necessitate a fine granularity, i.e., many narrow time windows. Existing solution methods cannot handle that level of granularity efficiently enough to be useful in practical settings. This award will yield solution methods that can handle precise representations of time, enabling carriers to provide, in a cost-effective manner, the short delivery times requested by their customers (some of the savings may even be passed on to the customers). These methods will help both the carriers and the companies they support compete in a global economy. As cost is primarily a function of (trailer) miles traveled, reducing miles can also lead to a reduction in emissions. By modeling time more precisely, carriers may also be able to better synchronize their transportation options, leading to greater use of greener options like rail.

While there is widespread use of discretizations of time in service network design models the fundamental question behind their use has not yet been answered; namely, "Can one produce a methodology that yields the benefits of discretizing time to a very fine degree without explicitly modeling each discrete point in time?" The research supported by this award will answer this question in the affirmative. A service network design problem defined on a very fine discretization of time will be studied so that consolidation opportunities can be accurately captured. An algorithmic framework that can be adapted to this problem will be developed, yielding an algorithm that can solve it in a runtime that is acceptable for use in practice. The framework will be primal-dual in nature, and algorithms that follow it will repeatedly solve service network design models, while dynamically adjusting the time representation. One representation will yield a relaxation of the problem (the dual), while the other will produce a feasible solution (the primal). The framework will be extended so that it may be used to initiate the development of algorithms for a broader class of service network design models. For example, models that value or choose the times when shipments are available for pickup and due for delivery, which impact how they can be consolidated with other shipments. Moreover, the framework will be extended to produce algorithms that can solve these models in reasonable run-times.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Improving the efficiency of logistics systems can lower costs and retail prices, reduce externalities such as pollution and traffic, and shorten the time customers wait for their orders to be delivered. The design of logistics systems often involves making decisions that have both a spatial and temporal component. A classic example is determining the route a vehicle should take, including the time at which it should dispatch from each location on that route. Operations Research models have long been used to assist in making these types of decisions. Such models are often constructed on a mathematical object known as a time-space network, wherein nodes encode both spatial and temporal information. These networks provide a rich framework for modeling different logistics settings and types of decisions. However, their use often entails significant computational challenges, as their size grows dramatically when longer planning horizons or narrower windows of time (half-hour intervals vs. day intervals) are encoded. As the sizes of these networks grow, so do the resulting models, making them significantly harder to solve, computationally-speaking. 

One of the primary trends in the expectations of customers of logistics systems is reduced delivery times. This trend can be seen in business-to-consumer markets, wherein more and more individuals expect shorter (e.g. same-day) delivery, and business-to-business markets, wherein more and more consumer product manufacturers engage in Just-in-Time-type manufacturing strategies. Coordinating the activities of a logistics system under short delivery windows requires prescribing decisions over narrower windows of time. As an example, in a fulfillment center for an organization that offers same-day delivery, knowing what vehicle to load from what door on a daily basis is not enough for operations. Instead, operations may need to know what vehicle to load from what door every half hour or every fifteen minutes. Thus, the trend towards shorter delivery times exacerbates one of the computational challenges associated with using time-space networks, as it requires the representation of narrower windows of time. 

Traditionally, time-space networks were built in a static, a priori, fashion. In this project, we developed an algorithmic framework called Dynamic Discretization Discovery (DDD), which generates a time-space network dynamically and in a way that only time windows that may be needed by operations are actually constructed. As a result, DDD retains the rich structure and benefits of time-space networks but avoids much of the computational challenge. With DDD, models defined on time-space networks that represent arbitrarily long planning horizons or arbitrarily narrow windows of time can be solved quickly. In addition, we demonstrated how DDD can be adapted to different issues encountered in transportation and logistics, such as the need to synchronize the visits of different vehicles to a facility as well as the need to move vehicles empty to position them for future moves. Finally, we demonstrated how DDD can be adapted to explicitly recognize the impact of traffic congestion on travel times. 

To disseminate the results of this project, we have written five papers that have been accepted or published in leading scientific journals. The paper that initially documents the framework has received the Best Paper award from the INFORMS Transportation Science & Logistics Society. We are currently writing three more papers based on the research done in this project, one of which focuses on how DDD can be adapted to logistics systems that employ autonomous vehicles. Relatedly, we have presented the findings of this project in over 15 scientific talks at conferences and universities around the world. Regarding the training of young scientists, this project supported or inspired the research of one post-doctoral researcher and three PhD students. Regarding the practical impact of this project, we are currently in discussions with freight transportation companies regarding how DDD can be used to help them plan their operations.
